awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1:   NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Proteins are natural, tiny molecular machines – often 10,000 times smaller than the width of a human hair – that play crucial roles in biology. Since their discovery almost 200 years ago, understanding their structures and functions has enabled scientists to learn about the processes that underpin life and solve scientific problems facing humanity. However, their tiny size makes them incredibly difficult to characterize and understand. One powerful way to determine the structures and functions of proteins is protein crystallography, a technique where X-rays interact with a highly ordered assembly of proteins, known as a single crystal. Unfortunately, obtaining protein single crystals represents a major bottleneck in this process because proteins can interact with each other in many ways that prevent them from forming highly ordered assemblies. This project aims to overcome this challenge using DNA – the genetic code of life – as a blueprint to define the interactions between proteins and thus control how they arrange into single crystals. Importantly, these single crystals will not only provide insight into the tiny world of proteins but will function as new, synthetic materials in their own right, useful as sustainable catalysts or energy conversion materials. Using DNA to control protein interactions and arrangement will allow crystals to be assembled by design. This work will help transform protein crystallography from an experiment of chance to an experiment of purpose to solve pressing societal needs in energy, sustainability, and medicine. Researchers at various stages of their careers (from undergraduate students to postdoctoral researchers) will benefit from the training provided by this project, and will disseminate their knowledge and skills in publications, presentations, and by engagement with students from typically underrepresented and marginalized groups through synergistic outreach activities.

PART 2:   TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Protein single crystals provide valuable, angstrom-level resolution and structural insight into the macromolecules that engender the infrastructure of life and represent a promising class of biomaterials with cooperative properties and concerted functions. This project seeks to understand the interactions that drive crystallization and discover a means to disrupt, reprogram, and redefine those interactions, using the programmability of DNA. This challenge will be approached from four complementary perspectives, each of which will yield valuable fundamental insight into protein crystallization: increasing the role of DNA in protein-DNA crystals; investigating how symmetry and valency affect crystallization; defining specific protein interfaces within crystals; and manipulating the conformations of flexible proteins so that they can be controlled and, ultimately, harnessed. These findings will result in design principles that will allow one to exploit the many distinct attributes of DNA, including its specific hybridization, tunable length, inherent flexibility, and tailorable interaction strength, to program the assembly of proteins. Therefore, achieving these objectives will not only render challenging proteins amenable to crystallographic analysis but also, importantly, open a new class of tailorable, programmed crystalline materials that can harness the intrinsic functionality of proteins. This project will generate new fundamental knowledge of how to control the interplay between DNA-DNA and protein-protein interactions, thereby empowering researchers with tools to engineer the structural outcomes of protein crystallization towards the creation of novel functional biomaterials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary 


Proteins are molecules that perform critical functions in living organisms, such as speeding up chemical reactions, transporting nutrients, and supporting cellular machinery. Scientists need to understand their individual structures in detail in order to comprehend how they organize and crystallize and ultimately how they function. However, the majority of proteins are not easily crystallized, in part due to the protein-protein interactions at play in these systems. As a result, over the last ~25 years, researchers have developed molecular tools and scaffolds to make crystallization possible for a wider range of proteins. This project leverages DNA, the blueprint for life, as a tool to program protein crystallization and assembly, advancing our understanding of protein-DNA interactions and their applications in biomaterials design. Specifically, researchers explored how DNA interactions, guided by native protein geometry, can regulate protein crystallization, allowing for precise control over symmetry, valency, and orientation in protein assemblies. By correlating DNA sequence design with crystal packing behavior, design guidelines were identified that utilize DNA length, complementarity, and attachment position to manipulate protein architecture.  


Over the course of this grant, several key advances were made in the field of DNA-programmable protein systems. Namely, methods were developed to enhance the symmetry and valency of proteins in synthetic oligomers, overcoming challenges in crystallization by increasing the ability of proteins to form ordered, lattice-like structures; and, DNA-based mechanisms were introduced to regulate protein folding and allosteric behavior, providing a foundation for the development of switchable, responsive materials. These findings represent significant strides in creating programmable, dynamic protein systems for diverse applications. Collectively, these advances provide new approaches for creating high-quality protein crystals, understanding protein structures, and designing functional materials that mimic or surpass natural systems, all of which are expected to benefit medicine, renewable energy, and more. 


Intellectual Merit 

 
This work significantly contributes to the fields of structural biology, materials science, and nanotechnology because new strategies for controlling protein crystallization and assembly were developed. The use of DNA as a programmable scaffold provides a platform to explore symmetry and valency in protein lattices, which enhances our ability to address crystallization challenges. In addition, this work offers insights into the role of DNA in regulating protein-protein interactions, with implications in drug development, structural determination, and biomaterial design. By demonstrating how DNA interactions can override or reprogram native protein interactions, this research introduces novel frameworks for creating dynamic, responsive protein architectures. These findings expand the toolkit for structural biologists and material scientists, enabling access to new protein configurations and functionalities. 


Broader Impacts 


This project, conducted in Professor Chad Mirkin's research group at Northwestern University and the International Institute for Nanotechnology (IIN), provided extensive training opportunities for students and postdoctoral researchers, where they gained expertise in cutting-edge methods, including protein-DNA conjugation, mass spectrometry, and crystallographic techniques. Importantly, research pursued under this award utilized Argonne National Laboratory's advanced photon source (i.e., synchrotron beamline). This specialized facility houses intense X-rays and state-of-the-art facilities that enabled precise structural characterization of protein-DNA conjugates that are not possible with standard laboratory equipment. This access not only advanced the project's scientific goals but also allowed researchers to train in cutting-edge techniques at a world-class institution, fostering collaboration and preparing the next generation of scientists to tackle complex challenges in structural biology and materials science. 


In addition, this grant actively supported the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM, recruiting women and underrepresented minority scientists and undergraduates who made meaningful contributions to the work. Supported researchers in the Mirkin group engaged with the public through outreach to local schools, where advanced concepts in protein design and nanotechnology were shared to inspire the next generation of scientists. Specifically, researchers participated in IIN-led programs including attending and interfacing with the IIN Frontier Seminar Series speakers which exposes young scholars to leaders in their field of research. In addition, researchers also participated in university-organized activities to promote inclusivity in STEM and disseminated the project's findings through accessible formats, raising awareness of how fundamental research can impact medicine, energy, and materials science. These efforts have fostered a diverse and inclusive scientific community while heightening public engagement with researchers in STEM fields and ideas in STEM.
